title: PLATELL'S PEOPLE: Girls doing stand up comedy teaches them how to stand up to men
text:
Headmistress Nina Gunson (above) is encouraging her pupils to learn comedy, offering them an eight-week course of stand-up classes

Trying to get your daughter into the right secondary school is a daunting task for any parent.

There are long hours spent researching possibilities, scouring the internet and worrying about league tables, pastoral care and much more.

Some parents have no choice but to accept what they are offered, of course.

But everyone wants their child to be happy, to excel — and to emerge sufficiently robust to cope with the tough, male-dominated outside world.

None of them will be concerned with whether their darling can do a comedy routine on stage. Yet that is the skill headmistress Nina Gunson is encouraging her pupils to learn, offering them an eight-week course of stand-up classes.

Hard-pressed parents who scrimped and saved the £13,359-a-year fees for her establishment, Sheffield High School For Girls, must think she’s having a laugh.

In fact, though, there is a brilliant logic to Mrs Gunson’s apparent lunacy. What do almost all young women suffer from? Lack of confidence, especially in a public forum.

In an age when teenagers are judged on looks and by their selfies and ‘likes’, there is great sense in empowering girls with the ability to just stand up and be who they are.

Mrs Gunson says the point of the course is to take teenagers out of their comfort zone by having them perform in front of each other, so they can be assessed on ingenuity, humour and the ability to think on their feet.

We all have a funny side, it’s just that we don’t know it. And as Mrs Gunson says, the course ‘teaches students to not take themselves too seriously, to improvise, to take risks and be a little bolder’.

It also provides lessons in how to cope with terrifying social situations — dealing with an audience when the jokes fall flat, heckling, a rising sense of panic in the public glare.

The head’s view is that if you can learn to handle all this, you’ll be better able to manage stressful situations in work and life.

And remember, some girls make scintillating comic performers. That’s how Phoebe Waller-Bridge started out, before creating Fleabag and Killing Eve, and contributing to the script for the next James Bond movie.

We can’t all be Fleabags but that doesn’t matter. Nina Gunson’s point is that you just have to learn to be confident in yourself.

Paul has been ‘liking’ lissom Lithuanian actress Bria Vinaite, 26 (pictured) on Instagram — though he stresses he is only expressing admiration for her baking!

A baker's fancy

Finally divorced this summer, Paul Hollywood, 53, first had an affair with Marcela Valladolid, his fellow judge on a U.S. version of Bake Off, then moved on to 24-year-old bar-maid Summer Monteys-Fullam, who dumped him last month.

Now he has been ‘liking’ lissom Lithuanian actress Bria Vinaite, 26 (pictured) on Instagram — though he stresses he is only expressing admiration for her baking!

Is there no nubile woman for whom podgy Paul won’t rise to the occasion?

Three cheers for Doreen

Fist-pumps for twicewidowed Doreen Jones, 81, who fought off a cashpoint robber trying to steal her pension money.

‘No, you’re not having my money. I’ve worked hard for that,’ the former factory worker told the young female thief, before grabbing her by the collar and flinging her across the pavement.

‘I was brought up in the War,’ she said. ‘I learned how to fight in the air-raid shelters. They picked the wrong one when they picked on Doreen.’

I’m just glad she didn’t hit out with her walking stick, or she’d be in court facing assault charges.

Launching a book of his late wife Linda’s photos, Paul McCartney waded into the Brexit debate, revealing that he thinks the EU referendum was ‘probably a mistake’.

Just let it be, Paul. We can work it out.

Betraying our boys

A double murder charge has been brought against a former British paratrooper over alleged atrocities on Bloody Sunday in Northern Ireland in 1972.

Now in his 60s, he is known as Soldier F. Every Prime Minister from Blair to May vowed we would end the hounding of our former soldiers.

Each one of those Prime Ministers should hang their head in shame.

With the disposable fashion industry creating a great deal of pollution, Strictly is doing its bit to save the planet. Bruno Tonioli is pictured above

With the disposable fashion industry creating a great deal of pollution, Strictly is doing its bit to save the planet.

The live audience are urged to use public transport, and its stars will stay in a ‘green hotel’.

Perhaps, to prevent any more hot air contributing to the greenhouse effect, they should also sack Bruno Tonioli (right).

Does Ma'am love Wham?

Forget her annus horribilis in 1992. This is fast becoming the Queen’s hebdomas horribilis (that’s Latin for disastrous week).

Yesterday, there were more Epstein allegations about Prince Andrew.

Throw in David Cameron blurting out that he’d asked Her Maj to help him over the Scottish referendum — and finally add the indiscretion, in the memoirs of the manager of Wham!, that she ‘asked’ for an audience with George Michael, as she was a fan. Don’t these people know one doesn’t care for careless whispers?

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says he didn’t realise in 2001 that ‘blacking up’ for an Arabian Nights fancy- dress party was racist.

Crikey, I wouldn’t have done it. When I nabbed Dad’s black shoe polish back in Australia in the Sixties to complete the Aladdin’s genie outfit Mum had made from some old Terylene curtains, he chided me for two reasons.

First, the Aboriginals with whom his mother had shared a waterhole would be offended. And second, that was his last tin of shoe polish.

Justin Trudeau dressed as Aladdin in 2001 to attend a party at West Point Grey Academy in Vancouver. He was 29

Westminster Wars

Ahead of his party’s conference, Jeremy Corbyn confesses that he finds the thought of becoming Prime Minister ‘daunting’. For most of us, it’s a good deal worse than that.

Buoyed by polls putting her party ahead of Labour, Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson ended her conference speech with arms outstretched, proclaiming that before her audience stood the country’s next Prime Minister.

Calm down, dear. You have as much chance of becoming PM as you do of modelling the autumn collection for Victoria’s Secret.

A truly shameful day for Corbyn’s party as its conference begins this weekend. Labour Friends of Israel — formed in 1957 — has withdrawn its promotional stand over fears for the safety of staff.

Greta's green army

Remarkable that it is little more than a year since Greta Thunberg, 16, staged a solitary protest outside the Swedish parliament, given the millions of young people across the globe who took her lead and walked out of school yesterday to protest against climate change.

Well done them. Yet one wonders how many realise their perfect world would mean never driving a car or catching a plane, never eating a Big Mac with fries and no more disposable fashion — just bicycles, vegan wraps and endless yards of sackcloth and ashes.

Or would the last of those get them in trouble with the CO2 police?

One wonders how many realise their perfect world would mean never driving a car or catching a plane, never eating a Big Mac with fries and no more disposable fashion — just bicycles, vegan wraps and endless yards of sackcloth and ashes

Tomorrow we’ll see England’s rugby team play Tonga in the World Cup. How odd that so many players feel the need to cover themselves in tattoos.

At least half the squad have them — and Jack Nowell and three of his teammates are inked almost all over. Poor lads.

In middle age, their arms will look as if they’re covered in varicose veins.

Listening to John Humphrys’s final appearance on Radio 4’s Today programme brought a tear not just to his eye but to mine.

I realised that, over the past 30 years, he has been the one constant man in my bedroom every morning. I suspect I am not alone in saying, Lord, I’ll miss him.
